truth: -  "In Python, a list is a mutable data structure that can contain elements of different types."
fiction: -  "In Python, a list is a magical data structure that can predict future elements."

truth: -  "A dictionary in Python is an unordered collection of data values that are used to store data values like a map."
fiction: -  "A dictionary in Python is a language translation tool that can translate English to Python code."

truth: -  "In Python, a set is an unordered collection of unique elements."
fiction: -  "In Python, a set is a collection of elements that always come in pairs."

truth: -  "A tuple in Python is an immutable sequence type."
fiction: -  "A tuple in Python is a mutable sequence type that can be resized."

truth: -  "The `append()` method in Python adds an item to the end of a list."
fiction: -  "The `append()` method in Python removes an item from the end of a list."

truth: -  "The `pop()` method in Python removes an item from a list and returns it."
fiction: -  "The `pop()` method in Python adds an item to a list and returns it."

truth: -  "The `keys()` method in Python returns a view object that displays a list of all the keys in the dictionary."
fiction: -  "The `keys()` method in Python locks the dictionary, preventing any changes to it."

truth: -  "The `add()` method in Python adds an element to a set."
fiction: -  "The `add()` method in Python subtracts an element from a set."

truth: -  "The `index()` method in Python returns the index of the specified element in the list."
fiction: -  "The `index()` method in Python shuffles the elements in the list."

truth: -  "The `remove()` method in Python removes the first occurrence of the element with the specified value."
fiction: -  "The `remove()` method in Python duplicates the first occurrence of the element with the specified value."

truth: -  "The `clear()` method in Python removes all the elements from a list."
fiction: -  "The `clear()` method in Python colors all the elements in a list."

truth: -  "The `values()` method in Python returns a view object that displays a list of all the values in the dictionary."
fiction: -  "The `values()` method in Python returns a view object that displays a list of all the keys in the dictionary."

truth: -  "The `update()` method in Python adds elements from a set (or any iterable) to the current set."
fiction: -  "The `update()` method in Python removes elements from a set (or any iterable) from the current set."

truth: -  "The `count()` method in Python returns the number of times a specified value appears in the tuple."
fiction: -  "The `count()` method in Python returns the sum of all the values in the tuple."

truth: -  "The `sort()` method in Python sorts the elements of a list in a specific order (ascending by default)."
fiction: -  "The `sort()` method in Python mixes up the elements of a list in a random order."

truth: -  "The `items()` method in Python returns a view object that displays a list of a dictionary's key-value tuple pairs."
fiction: -  "The `items()` method in Python returns a view object that displays a list of a dictionary's keys only."

truth: -  "The `discard()` method in Python removes the specified item from the set."
fiction: -  "The `discard()` method in Python adds the specified item to the set."

truth: -  "The `extend()` method in Python adds the specified list elements (or any iterable) to the end of the current list."
fiction: -  "The `extend()` method in Python removes the specified list elements (or any iterable) from the end of the current list."

truth: -  "The `insert()` method in Python adds an element at the specified position in the list."
fiction: -  "The `insert()` method in Python removes an element at the specified position in the list."

truth: -  "The `reverse()` method in Python reverses the order of the list."
fiction: -  "The `reverse()` method in Python arranges the list in alphabetical order."

truth: -  "The `copy()` method in Python returns a copy of the set."
fiction: -  "The `copy()` method in Python returns a mirror image of the set."
